verses.text: My son, do not forget my instruction, but let your heart keep my commands;
verses.comment: The opening address 'my son' shows the familial, instructional relationship, commonly seen as God’s fatherly guidance to his people. Spiritual tradition often sees this as divine wisdom inviting us to obedience.

verses.text: for they will add length of days, years of life, and peace to you.
verses.comment: Obedience is linked not just with physical longevity but inner peace—interpreted both as earthly blessing and spiritual harmony.

verses.text: Let kindness and truth not leave you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart;
verses.comment: Tradition reads ‘tablet of your heart’ as the moral law inscribed within—a precursor to the New Covenant written on hearts (Jer. 31:33; Heb. 8:10).

verses.text: So you will find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and man.
verses.comment: This echoes Christ growing in favor with God and man (Luke 2:52)—obedience and virtue produce harmony with God and neighbor.

verses.text: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and do not rely on your own understanding;
verses.comment: Reliance on divine wisdom is foundational. This anticipates later Christian teaching to trust God over human reasoning (see James 1:5).

verses.text: In all your ways acknowledge Him, and He will make your paths straight.
verses.comment: Total surrender to God’s providence—compare with Jesus’ ‘Thy will be done’ (Matt. 6:10).

verses.text: Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the LORD and turn away from evil.
verses.comment: Humility before God recalls the beatitudes, ‘Blessed are the poor in spirit’ (Matt. 5:3).

verses.text: It will be healing for your body and refreshment for your bones.
verses.comment: Biblical wisdom is holistic—both spiritual and physical health are promised.

verses.text: Honor the LORD with your wealth and with the firstfruits of all your produce;
verses.comment: Offering the first and best is an old practice—prefigures deeper spiritual sacrifices (see Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: then your barns will be filled with abundance, and your vats will overflow with new wine.
verses.comment: Material blessing is attached to spiritual fidelity. Tradition sees this as both literal and anticipating spiritual abundance (John 10:10).

verses.text: My son, do not despise the LORD’s discipline or resent His correction;
verses.comment: Discipline is corrective, rooted in love—see Hebrews 12’s interpretation in the context of suffering and sanctification.

verses.text: for the LORD disciplines those He loves, as a father the son in whom he delights.
verses.comment: God’s discipline reflects divine love—spiritual maturity comes through loving correction.

verses.text: Blessed is the one who finds wisdom, and the one who gains understanding,
verses.comment: Beatitude structure—parallels Jesus’ ‘Blessed are…’ teachings.

verses.text: for the profit from her is better than silver and her gain more than fine gold.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified as a woman, foreshadowing later allegorical associations with divine wisdom or even ‘the Word’ (John 1:1).

verses.text: She is more precious than jewels, and nothing you desire can compare with her.
verses.comment: Portrayal of wisdom as supremely valuable is central to biblical tradition, elevating virtue over material wealth.

verses.text: Long life is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor.
verses.comment: Both temporal blessings and spiritual gifts are in wisdom's hands—interpreted holistically by Christian tradition.

verses.text: Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace.
verses.comment: Peace from wisdom prefigures Christ as ‘Prince of Peace’ (Isa. 9:6).

verses.text: She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her; those who grasp her will be blessed.
verses.comment: ‘Tree of life’ links to Eden and eternal life imagery in Revelation—Christian tradition sees wisdom as leading to life with God.

verses.text: By wisdom the LORD founded the earth, by understanding He established the heavens;
verses.comment: Creation by wisdom points toward Christ, the Word, as agent of creation (John 1:1-3; Col. 1:16).

verses.text: by His knowledge the deeps broke open, and the clouds drop down dew.
verses.comment: Wisdom oversees all creation’s order, including water—a sign of blessing and outpouring.

verses.text: My son, do not let sound wisdom and discernment leave you; keep them before your eyes;
verses.comment: ‘Sound wisdom’ and ‘discernment’ link to the spiritual role of tradition safeguarding truth over time.

verses.text: and they will be life to your soul and adornment around your neck.
verses.comment: Adornments point to spiritual beauty—echoed in later Christian teaching (1 Peter 3:4).

verses.text: Then you will walk safely on your way, and your foot will not stumble.
verses.comment: God’s guidance provides sure footing—links to angelic guardianship (Ps. 91:11-12).

verses.text: When you lie down, you will not be afraid; when you rest, your sleep will be sweet.
verses.comment: True wisdom provides peace even while asleep—see also Ps. 4:8, which connects peace, trust, and rest.

verses.text: Do not be afraid of sudden terror, nor of the destruction of the wicked when it comes;
verses.comment: Security in God frees from anxiety despite surrounding evil.

verses.text: for the LORD will be your confidence and keep your foot from being caught.
verses.comment: Divine protection is promised to those who trust—seen as the assurance enjoyed by those walking faithfully with God.

verses.text: Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to act.
verses.comment: Doing good is a sacred duty—prefigures teachings on works of mercy.

verses.text: Do not say to your neighbor, 'Go and come back; tomorrow I will give it,' when you have it with you now.
verses.comment: Prompt charity is favored over procrastinated kindness—parallels New Testament concern for immediate love of neighbor.

verses.text: Do not plot evil against your neighbor, who lives trustfully beside you.
verses.comment: Reinforcement of command to love one’s neighbor—central to both Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: Do not accuse a man for no reason, when he has done you no harm.
verses.comment: Integrity in speech is part of biblical justice—also seen in Jesus’ teaching on judging rightly.

verses.text: Do not envy a violent man or choose any of his ways;
verses.comment: Rejecting violence is a prophetic theme—wisdom is opposed to worldly strength.

verses.text: for the devious are detestable to the LORD, but He is intimate with the upright.
verses.comment: God’s friendship is reserved for the innocent—intimacy with God is a strong biblical motif.

verses.text: The LORD’s curse is on the house of the wicked, but He blesses the dwelling of the righteous.
verses.comment: Blessing and curse—central to the covenant relationship. Spiritual tradition expands this to blessings upon family and household derived from fidelity.

verses.text: He scoffs at the scoffers, but gives grace to the humble.
verses.comment: Humility is commended—echoes the ‘God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble’ teaching, foundational to Christian spirituality.

verses.text: The wise will inherit honor, but fools get disgrace.
verses.comment: Inheritance of honor by the wise anticipates New Testament teaching on eternal reward for faithful living.
